blocks.value: St. Alphonsa of the Immaculate Conception (Anna Muttathupadathu) was born in 1910 in Kerala, India. She faced many trials from an early age, including the death of her mother when she was three months old. Alphonsa felt called to religious life and faced family opposition, even enduring an accident that left her partially disabled.

She entered the Franciscan Clarist Congregation and took the name Alphonsa. Throughout her life, she suffered from numerous illnesses and physical ailments, which she offered up to God with great faith and patience. She bore her sufferings with joy and saw them as a participation in Christ's Passion.

St. Alphonsa died on July 28, 1946. She was canonized by Pope Benedict XVI on October 12, 2008, becoming the first woman of Indian origin to be canonized as a saint. She is known as the "Patroness of Suffering Souls."
